bestBHT.bht: Jesus affirms that John the Baptist fulfilled the role of Elijah, which went against the common Jewish expectation of Elijah coming in person before the end. If the Jews were willing to receive it, they would understand that John is the promised Elijah. However, their prevalent belief in Elijah rising from the dead hindered many from accepting this truth. Jesus challenges their unwillingness to receive the statement about John's high place, emphasizing that those with ears to hear should listen.

Henry Alford: The if ye will (are willing to) receive it must be taken as referring to the partial sense of the fulfilment implied.
For it was (and is to this day) the belief of the Jews that Elias in person should come before the end.
The belief of the Jews that Elias in person should come before the end.
Albert Barnes: If ye will receive it - This is a mode of speaking implying that the doctrine which he was about to state was different from their common views; that he was about to state something which varied from the common expectation, and which therefore they might be disposed to reject.
An account of him is found in the first and second books of Kings. He was a distinguished prophet, and was taken up to heaven in a chariot of fire, 2 Kings 2:11.
This prevalent belief was the reason why he used the words 'if ye will receive it,' implying that the affirmation that 'John' was the promised Elijah was a doctrine contrary to their expectation.
Marvin Vincent: If ye are willing or disposed.
There would naturally be an unwillingness to receive the statement about John's high place.
John Calvin: Our Lord’s meaning therefore is, that the great and dreadful day of the Lord, which Malachi described, is now beheld by the Jews, when Elijah, who was there promised, discharges his office as a herald.
Again, by this exception, if you are willing to receive it, he glances at their hardened obstinacy, in maliciously shutting their eyes against the clearest light.

Christ does not mean that John’s official character depends on their approbation; but having declared that he is Elijah, he charges them with carelessness and ingratitude if he does not obtain that respect to which he is entitled.
Philip Schaff: The popular notions on the whole subject of prophecy were incorrect; for in the day of fulfilment our Lord thus prefaces an explanation.
Not the entire fulfilment of the prophecy, for John himself (John 1:21) said he was not Elijah, and our Lord afterwards intimated that another coming of Elijah is to be expected (Matthew 17:11).
The Jews expected that Elijah would rise from the dead, hence many would not receive it.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus affirms that John is the Elijah of promise who has come already."
He emphasizes the point: 'He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.'
John Gill: this same person, 'John the Baptist', is Elias, which was for to come
he that was intended by Elias, that was said should come
Christ, and he, say nothing contrary to, and irreconcilable, as the Jew suggests, with each other

bhtAttempts.bht: If the Jews were willing to receive it, they would understand that John the Baptist fulfilled the role of Elijah. This notion was contrary to their common expectations, as they believed that the literal Elijah would appear before the end. Jesus affirms that John is the promised Elijah who has already come, emphasizing this point and urging those with ears to hear to listen. The prevalent belief in the Jews' expectation of Elijah rising from the dead prevented many from accepting this truth. Our Lord challenges their hardened obstinacy and accuses them of carelessness and ingratitude if they fail to respect John's rightful place as Elijah. The Jews' incorrect notions about prophecy led Christ to preface his explanation with the phrase if you will receive it. The great and dreadful day of the Lord, described in Malachi, is considered by our Lord as unfolding before their eyes with John fulfilling his role as a herald.

The great and dreadful day of the Lord is considered by our Lord as unfolding before their eyes with John fulfilling his role as a herald.

Jesus affirms that John the Baptist fulfilled the role of Elijah, as he is the Elijah of promise who has already come. This was contrary to the belief of the Jews that Elijah in person would come before the end. The prevalent belief hindered many from receiving this truth about John's high place. Jesus challenges their unwillingness to accept it and emphasizes the importance of those with ears to hear.
